title: South Park creators 'apologise' to China after controversial episode
text:
The Band in China episode sparked the furore of the Chinese government (Picture: South Park Studios)

South Park creators released an ‘official apology’ to China after an episode mocking Hollywood for catering to the Chinese government saw Beijing delete all content of the comedy show from local servers.

The most recent episode of South Park, Band in China, got plenty of attention for its critique of the way Hollywood often carefully shapes its content to avoid offending Chinese government censors.

But in a case of art imitating real life, the Chinese government have fought back by deleting virtually every clip, episode and online discussion of the show from Chinese streaming services, social media and even fan pages, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

In response South Park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker posted this faux apology to Twitter along with a link to the episode: ‘Like the NBA we welcome the Chinese censors into our homes and into our hearts. We too love money more than freedom and democracy. Xi doesn’t look just like Winnie the Pooh at all.’

That’s quite an ‘apology’ (Picture: Twitter)

They then urged people to tune into their 300th episode before continuing their message.

‘Long live the Communist Party of China! May this autumn’s sorghum harvest be bountiful! We good now China?’

Apparently it is now near impossible to find a trace of South Park anywhere on the Chinese internet – from Weibo, to Youku, to Tieba – any threads, discussions, clips and episodes have been removed or are no longer functional.

The Band in China episode featured a pair of storylines critical of China.

South Park have never been known to shy away from controversy (Picture: South Park Studios)

One involves Randy getting caught attempting to sell weed in China and getting sent to a work camp similar to those Beijing has been using in Xinjiang Province to hold as many as a million Chinese Muslims for political indoctrination – where he runs into an imprisoned Winnie the Pooh.

A second plot follows Stan, Jimmy, Kenny and Butters forming a metal band, which becomes popular and attracts the attention of a manager who wants to make a film about them but then the script keeps changing so the film can safely be distributed in China.

The harsh response is unsurprising given that China’s government has even been known to censor any mention or appearance of Winnie the Pooh because he has become a symbol of the resistance, with local internet users compare Chinese president Xi Jinping to the character.

‘Now I know how Hollywood writers feel,’ Stan says at one point while a Chinese guard watches over him and alters his work while he writes the script.

Several shots are taken at Disney, including a scene where Mickey Mouse shows up to make sure all his employees – other Marvel and Disney cartoon characters – play ball with the Chinese authorities.
